title: Progress toward Mapping Nanoscale Carrier and Structural Dynamics in Silicon using Ultrafast TEM-Electron Energy-Loss Spectroscopy
content: We will discuss our current progress of performing and interpreting ultrafast electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) in a transmission electron microscope (TEM), including the accuracy of the theoretical methods used to interpret the data, the experimental challenges, and early findings on a silicon (Si) thin film membrane. EELS measures a material’s chemical and structural properties ranging from collective oscillations such as phonons and plasmons to the atomic oxidation state and local coordination [1]. Ultrafast electron microscopy (UEM) could bring high spatiotemporal resolution to EELS, allowing, for example, the nanoscale mapping of charge recombination and transport. A myriad of studies have focused on the low-loss (0 – 100 eV) region due to the larger cross-section for inelastic scattering where surface plasmon and optical near-field excitations occur [2]. Only a few studies have reported transient core-loss EELS (> 100 eV) in the TEM which would allow synchrotron types of information to be obtained [3].
